I knew a trick like this that works with toddlers and small children, especially if they’re sleepy or acting up. I explained to a woman whose son was crying and upset. She had just placed him in a banana stroller, a familiar and inexpensive one many parents buy. I went over to her and whispered, “gently rock him from side to side,” which she did. In about 3 minutes the boy was sound asleep. I told her that the sideway motion is the same motion of a pregnant woman with the baby still inside. Each time she walks, the baby is gently rocked side to side. So that it becomes an inborn experience a person never forgets. Put me in a rocking chair and guess who falls asleep. It may be forward and backwards but the gentle rocking motion of an unborn child
kicks in and off to slumberland you go. That’s why a woman holding a baby will rock it side to side to make it fall asleep. It has to be a gentle rocking motion to get your brain to remember, I’m 78 and it still puts me to sleep in minutes.

Guide And Tips For Your New Baby

First of all, CONGRATULATIONS! You are having a new baby! Now, on to the serious stuff. You are going to get yourself prepared for your new baby, mentally, physically and you will need to adjust your house and car for the new baby too!

Mentally preparing for the new baby here

Tips Physically preparing for the new baby here

Guide And Tips For Your New Baby

First of all, CONGRATULATIONS! You are having a new baby! Now, on to the serious stuff. You are going to get yourself prepared for your new baby, mentally, physically and you will need to adjust your house and car for the new baby too!

Mentally preparing for the new baby here

Remember this, women adjust to having a new baby faster than men; so, do not expect husbands to start being all fatherly after the pregnancy is announced. They are not like that. Women adjust better to the new baby, mentally, because they experience physical, emotional and psychological changes. These changes help them adjust to the new baby quicker. However, men start feeling the new baby when they see the bump or feel the flicker of baby movement over mommy’s belly.

Tips Physically preparing for the new baby here

There is nothing much a new father can do to prepare to the new baby. What needs to be done by a father needs to be done BEFORE the new baby is conceived. However, the new father can try quitting smoking, quitting drinking and other vices once the new baby is conceived. The new mother needs to do the same too.

The commentators' theories as to why this is effective are insufficient and seem to just be unsupported guesses. A 45 degree angle doesn't suddenly present new stimuli (or even if it does that isn't why this works, since baby's encounter new stimuli all the time). More likely, either the 45 degree angle forces the baby to have to stiffen its neck to keep its head up (since a baby's head is disproportionately heavy) or it really has nothing at all to do with the effectiveness of this method, and is simply the easiest angle to hold the baby this way.

I'm reading thru the comments and I feel so bad for some of you. I now have 2 daughters in their mid to late 20's. When they were infants and toddlers they were amazing. They both slept thru the night within a few weeks of coming home from the hospital. They potty trained quickly, the eldest walked early, I always got comments on how polite/well behaved they were and still are to this day. The only issues I had with them were that even tho I wanted to breastfeed I was/am ill and my body couldn't produce enough milk for my first daughter so I had to supplement with formula. I was prepared for this with my youngest and with my doctor's help I was able to breastfeed for the full 6 months I wanted to. However, I had to work the evening she started on formula and after just 2 or 3 hours my father in law, who was babysitting alone for the first time, called me and said she was tossing up and crying. I thought maybe he was just a little overwhelmed so I gave him some basic instructions to calm her and get her to sleep. 2 hours later he called again and said she was still crying and still tossing up. That was so out of the ordinary that I called in a replacement, called my husband and headed home. We drove an hour to the hospital and the doctor examined her and thank goodness she was perfectly fine, she was simply lactose intolerant. He gave us a couple tins of soy formula and sent us home with a much happier baby. The soy formula smelled horrible and babies often spit up while being burped after they eat and they drool quite a bit, turns out regurgitated soy formula smells even worse. A small price to pay to have her cooing and gurgling again.

❤️🗣🔎 I can explain exactly what's happening.. the doctor is doing a few things at once that is taking pressure off a vertebrae. He is essentially opening or expanding the ribcage by crossing the arms. He is also slightly tractioning the back by having baby at that angle. Thirdly by doctor rocking baby's butt only, he is creating a pivot point in the spinal column where any "restrictions" can be loosened or relieved. These restricted vertebrae in the spinal column have nerves in them that are slightly compressed. Causing discomfort for baby. These same nerves supply the stomach with information to produce HCL or stomach acid to break down food. If baby's nerves have too much pressure, proper signals to produce HCL after baby eats will not be met. Resulting in food that is not being broken down properly and simply sitting and rotting in the stomach. This typically results in baby with gas build up and discomfort. Baby will cry all night. This is why put putting them in a car seat will sometimes work. It takes pressure off a compressed nerve. This is similar to finding relief in poping a certain part of your back after a meal and feeling like you can digest food better.

Hello I have an improved version of the American pediatrician's technique to calm a crying baby. It's simpler and tested for up to 5 months :

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1BdqPKPHgxM

In his video the pediatrician holds the baby at arm's length while holding his chin and blocking both arms with one hand, the other hand carries it, then he makes him go up and down as he moves forward. It's very effective, but ...

- When the baby becomes heavier, already a week or two, you start to feel the weight.
- It is difficult to hold both arms and chin, need a calm baby and be very muscular.
- The baby becomes heavier and very difficult to maintain, not to mention the risks of falling. With my wife we ​​only made it above the bed or the sofa.

After reflection, we wondered why this method works? And we wondered if it is not the sensation of acceleration and deceleration that calms the child? Sensation that we know in elevators or rides at sensations. So I tried to reproduce these sensations by not holding the baby at arm's length but carrying it against me. And surprise ! it works, even better. After having tested it ourselves with our daughter, we had it tested by relatives and the result was positive.

After this discovery, I thought of all these parents who take their baby to take a ride in order to calm him down. It is the same thing, are the slight accelerations and decelerations that have a calming effect on him.

It's up to you to test and let me know your comments. I really need your positive or negative feedback, thanks;)

Picking up and thereby changing the baby's position gives relief to the auricle and vestibule of the inner ear. This was established through Child Development research many decades ago. Folding the arms across the chest mimics swaddling the child tightly with the arms in that same position. I'm not a medical person, nor even a parent, but I learned about the inner ear at university. I learned about the arms across the chest when I was training to become a baby holder for premature and sick infants. Whenever possible I held the baby such that its head was next to my heart because that sound is similar to mom's heartbeat when the baby was still in the womb.
I trained myself to lower my respiration to 2 and 1/4 breaths per minute while holding a baby. This helped to induce their own calmness and significantly lowered their own heart rate and respiration rate as they relaxed. I once held a baby who was on withdrawal from drugs and was having a mini convulsion every 3 seconds. I was told don't worry the baby won't be quiet. I did my breathing exercise and the baby's convulsions became sporadic, and eventually stopped completely. I held the baby for another 40 minutes. After laying the baby down I stood by the quiet bed for another 20 minutes before I left the unit.
As I passed by, the nurse looked at me and asked "Who are you?" I replied " Nobody special, but my nephew calls me Uncle Natewatl."
Live and learn.
